src_intro: ^You will find these books next to an event that uses Ink.
^They usually contain the Ink script used for the event.
^Lines usually start with a greater-than sign, in order to prevent the Ink parser from recognising cast tags, like this:
^>This is a line from the Ink script.
hello_world: ^This text comes from an Ink script.
^Each line in Ink becomes a new message window in RPG Maker.
^This isn't much use by itself though, because we have no control over the message box!
^You can use any escape codes you normally use in RPG Maker, for example:
^You need to use \C[1]Two\C backslashes every place you would normally only use one.
^You also need a backslash in front of any {}. See the "script.ink" file to see how the escape codes in this message were done.

message_styles: ^We can change message box styles using hashtags in Ink.
^The #dim hashtag shows a message box using the "Dim" background.
^The #transparent hashtag shows a message box using the "Transparent" background.
^You can control window position with #top, #middle and #bottom. This one is using #middle.
^Position and background can be combined, just like in RPG Maker. This is #top #dim.

choices: ^Any branches in Ink will be shown as choices in RPG Maker, like this:
script_style_dialog: ^Syd: This dialogue uses the "script" format. It is a convenient way to show messages with automatic name boxes and face images.
^R: How do you use the script format?
^Syd: Just write a line in your ink file starting with a name, a colon, and whatever you want that person to say.
^Syd: For example, if you have this line: Syd: Hi!
^Syd: Check the book next to me to see how it's done.

changing_the_cast: ^Now we're going to play with cast(). See the "dramatis_personae" knot in script.ink for the original definitions in case you get lost.
^Reid is linked to an actor, so it's easy to change his details. We're going to pause Ink for a bit to allow the RPG Maker actions alter the actor for a bit.
^Now we're back! And now Reid is...

voiceover: ^You can use the #audio(sound effect name) hashtag to do voiceovers and play other sound effects.
^Audio is automatically stopped when the dialog is closed.

when_ink_is_initialised: ^Syd: Ink is initialised when you first call it. It is NOT initialised when the game starts!

c-3: ^R: Congratulations on beating or running away from the Fox Scribe!
^R: The choice used an Ink condition in front of a choice. The condition used the rmmv_switch() function, which checks the value of a switch in RPG Maker.
^R: (It works in RPG Maker MV and MZ, even though it's called rmmv_switch!)
^R: You can do the same thing using linked variables and switches, but rmmv_switch is convenient for one-offs like this.

s2: ^R: You can embed dialogue directly into the sequence if you like, but the lines get a little long, and any hashtags you use must apply to the whole line.

ink_sequences1: ^R: This description is nice, but it would be boring if I repeated the same one each time.
ink_sequences2: ^R: So it's lucky that a different description is used each time!
ink_sequences4: ^R: Ink has other kinds of alternatives for rotating content. This is a cycle, but give sequences, shuffles, and once-only a try too!
ink_sequences5: ^R: It will loop back to the first description, but it's still more interesting this way.
mystery_characters: ^Myst: Sometimes you'd like a character's name to be a secret in some dialogues, and reveal the name later.
